label: Broader
evidence: Phage endolysin is a broader concept than Phage endolysin N-acetylmuramoyl-L-alanine amidase (EC 3.5.1.28). Phage endolysins are enzymes produced by bacteriophages to degrade the bacterial cell wall, facilitating the release of new viral particles. They can have various enzymatic activities, including glycosidase, amidase, and endopeptidase activities. Phage endolysin N-acetylmuramoyl-L-alanine amidase is a specific type of phage endolysin that catalyzes the hydrolysis of the amide bond between N-acetylmuramoyl residues and L-alanine in the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell walls. Therefore, while all N-acetylmuramoyl-L-alanine amidases are phage endolysins, not all phage endolysins are N-acetylmuramoyl-L-alanine amidases.**

label: Related

The HNH homing endonuclease is characterized by the presence of the HNH motif, a conserved sequence that is involved in the catalytic activity of the enzyme. Phage homing endonucleases, on the other hand, are a subset of homing endonucleases found in bacteriophages, which are viruses that infect bacteria. While phage homing endonucleases can include HNH endonucleases, they are not limited to this type and can encompass other motifs and structures. Therefore, while they share functional similarities and can overlap, they are not identical or synonymous, making them related but distinct entities.**
